dcterms:title: At the Relton Arms : ELTec edition : ELTeC edition
dcterms:creator: Sharp, Evelyn (1869-1955)
dcterms:publisher: COST Action "Distant Reading for European Literary History" (CA16204)
dct:description: A West End musician, Digby Raleigh, becomes entangled in a love triangle with the unconventional Lady Joan Relton and the innocent Norah Bisley while navigating family obligations at Murville Manor and the little town of Relton. Misunderstandings, a secret past, and a presumed death (and return) complicate engagements and loyalties, exposing the characters' differing attitudes to marriage, art, and duty. The novel satirises provincial society, fashionable philanthropy, and Bohemian artistic pretensions against a backdrop of late Victorian manners. Ultimately domestic attachments and practical kindness reshape relationships more than ideals or rhetoric.

mainCharacters.name: Digby Raleigh
mainCharacters.profile: A passionate West End musician and widower, father to a small son (Sonny); idealistic, given to metaphysical and Socialist talk, and artistically devoted. He is sincere and generous but awkward in affairs of the heart, whose good intentions produce entanglements and comic tragedy.

mainCharacters.name: Lady Joan Relton
mainCharacters.profile: A wealthy, witty, unconventional young woman who delights in shocking society and in exercising her independence. Charismatic, self-possessed and sometimes selfish, she drives much of the plot by her flirtations, pragmatic choices, and later philanthropic experiments.

mainCharacters.name: Norah Bisley
mainCharacters.profile: A gentle, innocent provincial woman, emotionally sincere and morally steady; she becomes Digby’s genuine betrothed and later wife. Her patience, practical kindness, and quiet strength contrast with the worldliness of Lady Joan and help stabilise Digby’s life.

mainCharacters.name: Jack Raleigh
mainCharacters.profile: The Squire's handsome, improvident younger son: a charming, impulsive drifter given to flirtation and debt. His presumed death and later return create the central crisis—testing loyalties, exposing hypocrisies, and prompting key decisions by Lady Joan and others.
